text: so uh a moral Revolution like a
scientific revolution and it was
actually thinking about the analogy
between ethics and Science and thinking
about Thomas structure of
scientific revolutions that got me into
this in the first place moral
revolutions like scientific revolutions
take longer than political revolutions
they take a generation usually um and in
many of them there
are uh small groups not usually just one
person but small groups of people who
are crucial in setting the process in
motion uh we think rightly of William
wilburforce as a crucial figure in
abolitionism in Europe in in Britain in
in uh beginning to articulate clearly
and forcefully the arguments against the
wickedness of the slave trade um those
people do their work in part by creating
organizations organizations of people
who commit themselves to the new Norm
the anti- footbinding Societies in China
are very important in this they commit
themselves to the new Norm when you
joined one of those societies you said I
won't bind the feet of my daughters and
I won't let my sons marry uh women whose
feet are bound you you you sort of
Double Deal and if you're a woman you
said I will unbind my own feet you
commit yourself to the new practice U
abolitionists joined societies where
they committed themselves not just to
not having slaves but for example in the
case of Britain to not consuming sugar
because sugar was produced through slave
plantations and uh hundreds of thousands
of people in England in the late 19 18th
century stopped using sugar which was
just beginning to be an important
consumer product because they associated
with slavery so you you you if you
create
organizations which commit themselves to
implementing the norm uh not just as a
norm of morality but as a norm of as a
Convention of everyday life as it were
as something that you're going to live
by then you can be one of the key
figures in uh if you create such
institutions you can you can begin one
of these uh revolutions I think that in
in all of these sorts of cases uh there
was there was an anti- dueling Society u
in England in all of these cases it's
very important to get people organized
around the new
norm and it's kind of exciting to be in
those societies because of the thing I
said earlier which is that uh you can
see that you're on the right side
because other people well the people who
are engaging in the old Norm the norm
you're challenging already
know in their hearts part of what they
in part part of their hearts at least
that what they're doing is objectionable
in some way that it's causing
unnecessary pain that it's it's denying
people things that they're entitled to
uh that it's crazy in the case of
dueling it's just irrational uh because
of course in a duel who wins doesn't
depend on who's right well it's crazy to
have a practice that's meant to put
something right where who win wins
doesn't depend on who's right everybody
knew this was crazy and yet nevertheless
uh they went ahead with it anyway so um
there's a if you you can begin one of
these processes you can help to begin
one of these processes I think by
articulating clearly uh the the sort of
arguments and getting them connected
with with dishonor as opposed to honor
and by organizing groups of people who
are committed to the new norm and if we
we think about people who are important
in these processes they like um kangu
way who was an important figure in the
Chinese anti- footbinding movement or
like wilburforce who's an important
figure in abolition uh or like the Duke

important because of their role in these
